comment-body: The youth need to be hugely involved in this - it is their future we are deciding here, their voices deserve to be heard and acted on.
Dogs should be kept on the leash at all times on/near wildlife hotspot beaches to prevent injuring wildlife, and this needs to be enforced.
Biodiversity needs to be defined in a way that suits Aotearoa, all of us, not a metro view, or pakeha view or rural.  We cant reverse time.
We should recognise and value our indigenous ecosystems for their contribution to global biodiversity. We've lost so much already
Biodiversity consultation needs to include experts from a variety of contexts in which experience and expertise has been gained.
The roles and responsibilities of various agencies needs to be clearer so public understand who is responsible for what
Community conservation groups be better supported through more funding, better access to information and minimising paperwork
Tourists should be charged slightly more for seeing e.g. a kiwi, than a NZ citizen, and that extra money should go towards conservation.
We need to act now, before it's too late, and future generations miss out on our wonderful nature.
We have taken so much from this land already. It's time to give back.
We don't deserve to call ourselves Kiwis if we won't make reasonable efforts to save the Kiwi, and our other precious native species.
New Zealanders don't see or interact enough with their native species so don't have a big enough drive to want to save them.
We need a plan to deal with cats in New Zealand.
Everyone can make a difference, even if it's something small like a backyard native bird feeder or a small donation to a conservation group.
More exposure to our unique endangered birdlife, like Sirocco the Kakapo, will help to raise awareness about why we need to save our species
More and larger predator-free ecosanctuaries on the mainland are a step in the right direction.
More public knowledge about the science behind 1080 and the work DoC do is needed for conservation efforts to move forwards.
There needs to be more education about conservation and its importance in schools.
Muttonbirding should no longer be allowed. We need to move on from the past and look towards the future of all species.
There should be a scheme for the trapping or shooting of wild / feral rabbits and the sale of their meat.  Far better than poisoning...
Iwi & small-scale land owners could use low productivity/erodible land for long-rotation totara and rimu plantations.= Habitat,fruit,timber.
We need more trees on hillsides and coastlines to avoid erosion.
Predators could be managed by the public at lower cost to DOC with a bounty incentive, resulting in more people outdoors for a good cause
Hunters spend more time in around indigenous and non-indigenous species than many other people, their advice should be sought and valued.
Our buildings should support biodiversity more e.g. more green walls and roofs, reuse of grey water, etc

We need to care for the foundations of the natural world (e.g. microbes, worms, beetles) and the insects, algae, lichens and other life at the bottom of the food chain, in addition to the big animals.
Alternatives to mowed lawns need to be more acceptable. Let a bit more wilderness into gardens
Economics and business aren't the problems. Selfishness is.
The Royal Society needs to exercise a primary authority here, not the government. The government are not experts.
Science and matauranga MƒÅori are both important, but we need more than just those two kinds of knowledge.
Clear and concise
A key part of the solution is changing the way most New Zealanders think.
Most New Zealanders currently believe pest and biodiversity management are somebody elses problem.
The solutions to our biodiversity and pest control problems already exist - we just need to be willing to pay what it really costs.
Responsible hunting of introduced species should be encouraged, & the right of a  responsible hunting community to do so should be protected
Eradicating predators would be more acheivable if less was spent on poison (1080) and public participation encouraged with a bounty system.
Game animals (deer, tahr, chamois, trout etc) must be recognised as a renewable source of conservation revenue, to be carefully managed.
Conservation minded hunters are valuable in their contribution to management of introduced species, and their efforts should encouraged more
Introduced species game animals (deer, tahr, chamois, etc) must be managed in partnership and consultation with the hunting community.
Democracy is great for engagement but expertise is important, too.
Biodiversity is too important for politicians to decide about. They need to enact what experts advise regardless of political desire.
People need to open-minded educate themselves on 1080 - I was unsure but after extensive research I see how absolutely necessary it is
Zoos should play a stronger role in educating us about biodiversity.
Voting in Hivemind is interesting and engaging, but it takes experts to figure out what really matters.
Tourism must be managed to protect biodiversity.
Biodiversity needs to happen where people can experience it.
Golf courses could be put to much better use, increasing biodiversity in towns and making it visible.
People should mow their lawns less, and let a bit more wilderness into their gardens.
We're running out of time.
Scholars in all disciplines need to contribute to this work, not only scientists and engineers.
Urban dwellers are too far from nature to know what needs to be done. Rural voices need to be raised alongside the urban majority.
Farmers have a lot of knowledge about land, plants and animals that needs to be valued and brought into the public conversation.
More diversity in farming (e.g. farm and sell breed-specific milks) would contribute culturally to our work on nature's diversity.
Diversifying New Zealand's culture will improve opportunities to support the diversity of nature. E.g we will become open to broader diets.
Soil health matters, too. Let's look after the microbes, worms, beetles and things at the foundation of the natural world.
Mowed lawns are a problem. We need alternatives to be made acceptable.
None of this is news. We've known it for decades, and everyone who's been resisting it all this time needs to get out of the way NOW.
Architects need to incorporate biodiversity provisions into building design.
We need to care for insects, algae, lichens and other life at the bottom of the food chain, in addition to the big animals.
Roadsides and berms need to be treated and valued as biodiverse wildlife space.
Land development must nourish the groundwater as a foundation for soil health, not drain it all to the sea.
Urban waterways need to be made into nature corridors and nature-compatible recreation spaces, not buried in pipes.
Cat owners should keep their cats indoors, or at least stop them from roaming free without supervision.
Home gardeners have a role to play through the plants and gardening methods that they choose.
Urban landscaping, such as city council plantings, need to prioritise biodiversity.
Town planning needs to prioritise biodiversity.
This isn't a MƒÅori-and-PƒÅkehƒÅ issue. It's an issue for all New Zealanders needing the diverse understanding that all cultures bring.
Biodiversity and environmental stewardships are fundamental obligations of landowners.
We are part of nature, not separate from it. Nature has no right separate from us, but when it falls, we fall too.
Make space for the young. The old who got us into this mess are not only stubborn, but essentially stupid.
Domestic cats need to be recognised as a serious but manageable threat to biodiversity.
We need to work on the biodiversity of the sea, as well as of the land.
Human beings need to manage and maintain ecosystems and biodiversity in perpetuity.
I no longer accept that it is economy versus ecology. A healthy biodiverse environment is essential for farming sustainability.
Sanctuaries, private, Maori & public
Conservation jobs should attract higher pay rates to attract and keep talented, knowledgeable and committed people
Native forest soil and ground plants must be protected from browsing mammals to maintain healthy forests, water quality and reduce erosion.
Although consultation with stakeholders is a good idea, the democratic process as it stands is too clunky to achieve conservation success
Participants deserve to be shown the voting on all the statements submitted.
NZ's economic interests need to be put aside for the moment, without our environment we have nothing.
My generation has been growing watching things get worse and worse, but we are powerless to stop it, as we essentially have no voice.
The future of Aotearoa's natural environment, ecosystems, biodiversity seems hopeless. It's too little, too late.
We need radical change to address the problems we've created. But our current systems may not allow for this to happen.
The way we currently produce animals for food is damaging our ecosystems
If people continue to see nature as a resource to be exploited, we will never make real change. We need to value it for it's own sake.
The processes of westernization, colonization, and capitalism underlie the erosion of our ecosystems.
We need to stop valuing economic systems over the natural ones they disrupt.
Our current farming practices are not sustainable
We need to assess the impact of all introduced species to our ecosystems, including those we economically benefit from
Animal agriculture has an undeniable negative impact on our environment, and serious measures  need to be taken to address this
Grazing should cease causing harm to our living freshwater ecosystems
When profit is made from degrading our forest, oceans, waterways, land and air it should be taxed to fund restoration and repair
The natural state of man is the  expression of such gratitude, appreciation and compassion that ALL animals love to be in his/her presence.
Us humans have destroyed this stunning country and planet - it‚Äôs is time to give back what we have stolen ‚Äî many hands make light work üôè
Stop using indiscriminate poisons. Stop lying to the public about the safety of poisons. Stop teaching kids you should kill harmless joeys .
Save our speecies , BAN1080
Ban 1080 easy let nature fix what you broke
Please stop using poisons in New Zealand.They are no tool they are killers of all species.There are better ways.Love Nature stop killing her
Whether they live in a city or in a rural area, every New Zealanders opinion matters.
DOC has very little support from the general public due to their obsession on poisoning our environment and food chain with 1080.
I no longer accept that it is economy or ecology.  Rather that a healthy biodiverse environment is essential for farming sustainability.
Be more careful about where poison is dropped. Read again the 1080 SDS.
Stick to trapping rather than poison in areas people can reach by foot/quad. Reduce non-target deaths by contamination of their food chain.
Ban aerial 1080 get more people involved lots of traps and proactive non toxic solutions its all there we just need to get off the poison
BAN TEN80
Give nature legal personhood similar to the Whanganui River. Nature should represented by trustees appointed by iwi and the govt, and have standing in planning law and the courts.
Give nature a legal persona and let it have standing in planning law and the courts, represented by trustees appointed by iwi and the govt
Current commercial monoculture forestry is damaging our environment. Mixed forestry with higher value species should be promoted
In the face of a changing climate, reslient practices and species will become increasingly important
The sale and use of pesticides and herbicides should be restricted with the aim of creating a totally organic environment
Community environmental effort will be constantly undermined by economy-based decision making unless there are major system changes
Man was created with domain over nature - we should use it. If it dies, it will be replaced - that's the nature of living things on earth
Establish a partnership between the agriculture industry and government to develop and promote farming practices that protect and restore our biodiversity
Threatened indigenous plants should be protected by stronger legal mechanisms
Biodiversity habitat and climate change response should go hand in hand
A stand-alone non-binding strategy will not be sufficient to ensure biodiversity protection
Farmers need to be encouraged to move away from dairy and beef farming to arable farming.
The government must commit $$ to an implementation plan for the Strategy
This consultation can be skewed by bloc-voting from anti-1080 partisans.
Hunting of wild pigeons/kereru should never be legal again, for any race.
Control of most introduced bird species is inadequate.
1080 is a cruel and indiscriminate poison with no antidote. Most people are against aerial 1080.
Man was created with domain over nature - we should use it, and it it dies it will be replaced - that's the nature of living things on earth
In rural NZ, private property does not give the right to destroy specie's habitat and homes, just because you "own" the land
We need more protection corridors that run from the sea to the mountains, managed to allow native species to thrive
as sea level rises, we should retreat and allow native plants and animals to migrate into the space we vacate - plants and birds need it
Why not put the Maui dolphins in the Napier aquarium to breed and raise money to help save them
New Zealanders care about nature and our native species
The resource management act review must address cumulative adverse effects - many minor losses add up to significant losses otherwise
Many private land owners will protect native biodiversity on their land if they know how to, and are assisted/encouraged
NZ is a unique world treasure  we need to assure it has a future
For all predators to be killed off new laws will be needed to enforce this plan across all lands.
Maori are being included in this plan because there's 1 million hectares of Maori land that needs to be poisoned.
There are many exciting new ways to properly engage with nature this plan isn't one of them.
Killing for conservation is an example of human logic being applied to natural systems, that operate outside of our proper understanding.
Rather than gaining a balanced view this survey is designed to channel people's thinking in a certain way. =Zero proper discussion.
NZ is being asked to allow a bureaucracy to impose a view of nature on natural systems we have little understanding of.
The world is in a continual state of change and evolution. As one plant or animal disappears another takes its place.
As no ecosystem is ever browser  or predator free trying to eliminate them completely is both undesirable and impossible.
Prohibiting dogs from entering forests with kiwis and beaches with nesting dotterels needs to be taken more seriously.
There aren't enough endemic bird species being bred in captivity.
Preventing the illegal ownership of possums and ferrets as pets needs to be enforced more seriously.
DOC have been starved of finance for many years and while that has been redressed slightly more backing is needed for biodiversity
Biodiversity habitat and climate change response should go hand in hand - plant specification, farming practice can contribute to both.
When NZ species are clearly doomed due to climate crisis, we must stop pest control - this will be pointless, so inhumane.
Returning forests to an unbrowsed state is nonsense. Moa browsed extensively from lowlands to alpine areas. Browsers are part of our nature!
Our livelihoods must be connected to restoring nature to shift from our degenerative economy and stop the global ecological collapse
Threatened Plants need legal protection
We need to find alternatives to using 1080 poison for pest control
There should be a working partnership between the agriculture industry & the government working towards biodiversity
The government should direct the agriculture industry to both improve biodiversity and to develop sustainably
Get locals to help identify and set up as many 'mainland sanctuaries' as possible.
Trapping for rats, etc should be fully subsidised on private property close to national and regional parks, and island sanctuaries so that native populations can expand beyond the protected areas
We need more advertising campaigns about NZ's unique flora and fauna so we feel the need to protect our species and so that we know what to do
Open-data commons, curating/visualising enviro, social & financial data frm ALL users of whenua will help us make decisions democratically
Distributed decisions re:land use must account/forecast impact across human, social, natural, production, intellectual & financial metrics
Pest plants are a significant threat to indigenous biodiversity.  More resources and focus is needed to address this issue.
More great advertising like this video with a call to specific action - tell Kiwis what we need to do to help protect our vulnerable species
Love your video on NZ's unique flora and fauna. We need more advertising campaigns like this so we feel the need to protect our species.
Private property close to national or regional parks should be fully subsidised for trapping rodents.
Time to bring back gorse inspections for land. The law used to be that gorse must be removed. What happened to that?
Time to subsidise backyard trapping in Auckland close to island sanctuaries before the birds start flying over and get eaten by our rats.
Kakapo need a warmer place to live than the deep South. Time to bring more up North where they once lived in abundance. So sad so many died.
We need to identify as many possible 'mainland sanctuaries' as possible. Get locals to identify potential habitats and get started.
The government needs to provide direction to the agriculture industry to both improve biodiversity and ensure sustainable development.
The strategy should include measures for improved connection and wellbeing of people.
We need a way to ensure enduring financial commitment of central and local government to action for the whole duration of the strategy.
Any biodiversity strategy governance should include young people to speak for the future generations
There needs to be continual shift towards the mindset that outdoor cats have a significant negative impact on native biodiversity
Eliminate populations of non-native species that are valued for recreational or economic reasons but that negatively impact native species e.g. tahr, trout
Allow seaweed aquaculture, which will improve biodiversity, sequester more carbon than trees and reduce ocean acidification
Populations of non-native species that have a recreational or economic benefit (eg tahr hunting, trout fishing) should not be maintained.
End aerial 180 drops
The biggest threat to biodiversity in our oceans and beaches is plastic pollution. We need to stop importing it, making it and buying it.
Clean up the Waikato river
Seaweed aquaculture will improve biodiversity,sequester more carbon than trees+reduce ocean acidification.Legislation currently prohibits it
Education standards should require educational field trips to natural spaces for all school children.
More no-take marine reserves should be created, especially in the habitat of endangered animals, like Maui dolphins and endangered seabirds
We could switch NZ's main meat source to wild deer/pig/trout/goat, hunting levels down so they are less impactful on natives
If we keep pigs/deer/trout, they should be made a mainstream food source (instead of farming) and try to control levels to feed people
For hunting/fishing, restricted areas could be made and require bookings to reduce number of hunters in bush at the same time.
Hapu should be involved BUT some may use that as an excuse to keep/exploit land which could be used for conservation. Word laws carefully
Instead of focusing on protecting flagship species, we should focus on protecting entire ecosystems, which may include those species.
I find this kind of participation frustrating because it does not, probably cannot, include deliberation with one's fellow citizens.
Instead of saving 'species' save environments where multiple species coexist ie areas where kiwi can thrive as well as other species
The clean water issue having farmers both hill country & flat land under the one umbrella is unfair as the situation is entirely different.
There needs to be a stronger emphasis on retaining our endemic invertebrate diversity. Without them our fragile ecosystem wouldn't exist.
Nature can manage itself. Humans are the cause of all perceived problems. Management is unnecessary. Leave wild places wild.
Allowing government/politicians to manage nature is the main problem. Stop poisoning our wild food.
Biodiversity means encouraging all forms of life to prosper. The current economic scarcity based system is unable to coexist with this idea.
Everything works for everything; we need to have sustainable systems, not endless consumption and growth.
Water management to prevent degradation is key to success in land and biodiversity management
Ownership of water rights should not allow degradation of the resource. Stronger management, quality and quantity standards are needed.
Particularly in urban areas, we need to give greater weight to definite benefits for all from trees, less to tiny risk of injury to 1.
The wisdom of nature is greater than our own. We have little understanding of what we are doing.
Protection and enhancement will mean different things, they need to be clear so everyone knows they are talking about the same things
genetic manipulation is best left to the experts, viruses.
The only way of rectifying the environmental issues is less humans. Either we control our numbers or nature will, unlikely to be "humane"
The "economy" is a subset of the environment, economics would have us believe it is separate as only money matters
It is neo-liberal economics, at its core it is a religion with a very savage hook, interest (usury it was called) which necessitates growth
nature has the right exist, what ignorant hubris, how disconnected is that statement from the world we live in?
Deer/pig/trout are excellent food source, we can never get rid of them so control and use as such
Forget the crown, NZ is for NZers. That is all we need to understand. Unfortunately most of our ruling class consider others before NZers...
Stewardship is not a race based decision, we are all homo sap spp, the sooner we all realise there is nowhere to run the better
We already know what the problem is, no amount of science or tech is going to change it. Overshoot it is called, all else is symptom.
Unfortunately the private landowner may do things to his/her land that are damaging for the country, we are all temporary utilisers of NZ
DOC cost per dead possum is about $25, so a $10 bounty gets lots of youngsters into the bush (connections all round) solves several issues.
Funding be given to gene research on changes in species that allow them to breed past sustainable levels and ways to return this to normal
Farming monocultures are harmful, funding should be given to research and promote diverse  systems of farming.
Water management to prevent degradation is key to success in land and bio management  while their management benefits water, they rely on it
Ownership of water rights should not allow degradation of the resource.
Ownership of land rights grant you the temporary use of it, the land continues in the community after you, it is not the right to degrade it
If climate change proceeds, there will come a point where we have to give up on protecting NZ biodiversity.
Gathering meat though hunting game species should  be considered as a valuable resource
The cost of monitoring the state and change of biodiversity values may exceed the cost of management
The best strategy is to give land back to Nature and allow natural processes to create new ecosystems.
The existing combination of introduced and native plants and animals are the ecosystems of the future.
The Maori perspective should not be bought, bent and manipulated in order to incorporate it into what is essentially a pakeha view.
All life is precious and interconnected. This should be the basis for any plan.
Biodiversity includes all life forms. In nature there are no such things as Pests. There is no such thing as being cruel to be kind.
More focus needs to be shifted from charismatic fauna to lesser known, threatened species.
There should be more onus on peer reviewed science in decision making that affects biodiversity, such as cat control.
the strategy needs to include most species. not just indigeous
I don't like using poisons  for pest control but necessary evil until something better is developed.
Decisions on funding for pest control are made by the same people and successful innovations developed by outsiders are dismissed
Barren farmed landscapes have become a mental health issue. They must have recognisable native vegetation within it.
Roadsides and other public land are currently pest plant corridors. Where possible this aspect must be eliminated.
The impacts of deer, pigs and trout need to be clearly stated and their cultural links dealt with.
Biodiversity values on private land can be a liability from a development perspective
Remove limitations placed on public engagement such as legislative barriers and eurocentric concepts of natural heritage to reduce harm.
We need governance that has the mandate to represent community groups & doesn't take western approaches to influence decision making spaces
We need to remove systemic and structural forces that impose harm to preserving our natural and cultural heritage.
We need to recognise the concept of cultural landscapes and the layers of meaning and connections within a landscape. Reverse western values
Herbicides and Pesticide use must be limited. Land clearing or change of land use that disrupts terrestrial ecosystems must stop.
We should innovate to become more inclusive of nature and biodiversity in our city/town designs.

I am female

the biodiversity strategy must be measureable
Please stop poisoning our lovely forests from the sky with deadly poison. Mammals and rural hunters are part of our diversity.
The protection and enhancement of our biodiversity does not have to cost huge amounts of money.
Protecting and enhancing our environment is good for our economy and our society.
Government should ensure that all riparian protected areas that is manages are fenced from stock damage to vegetation and water quality
Support and encouragement to protect nature & our threatened species is needed for farmers, fishers and others, as well as bottomline rules
Climate change adaptation should use nature-based solutions to build ecological resilience, and help maintain and restore nature
New Vision: Current and future generations connect with Aotearoa‚Äôs‚Äô healthy, abundant and thriving nature, restore it and are restored by it
Private property owners should be compensated to not develop their land and preserve biodiversity.
The underlying economic incentives need to changed to deliver on the biodiversity outcomes we are seeking.
The Strategy does not address the underlying economic incentives driving the continued loss of biodiversity e.g. through urban development
We must continue to develop innovative ways of educating young people about our biodiversity
No. Private sector caused the problems and will detract from efforts to repair as they seek profits above all else.
The science of how to fix this is already clear and known. Technological fixes are unnecessary.
Indigenous species absolutely require non-indigenous species to cope with the new, degraded ecosystem.
Seems too vague a statement to have any meaning
I don't believe any level of Govt have moral ground for deciding this, as they have all allowed this to happen in the first place
Also organic methods to ensure food isn't contaminated with toxins, as it currently is.
Restoration can't occur if destructive actions are ongoing. Stop poison spraying, land clearing, intensive farming.
The ecosystem that existed prior to 200 years ago is gone forever. All ecosystems, indigenous or not must be encouraged.
Indigenous biodiversity enhancement will buffer us from the impacts of climate change.
Te ao Maori regarding biodiversity / the environment and science should work together. Each perspective strengthens the other.
To achieve long term success (through 2070) innovative ways to educate current and future young people about our biodiversity are important
Farmers care about the land and are aiming to leave it in a better state for the next generation.
Introduced species are not inherently good or bad. Their place in our biodiversity depends on the impact of the specific species.
Research into CRISPR genome editing must be looked at as a potential pest control tool.
By 2070, nature in Aotearoa is healthy, abundant, and thriving
By 2070, nature in Aotearoa NZ should be healthy, abundant, and thriving
o protect and restore biodiversity and ecosystem services we must move away from a fixation on economic growth and towards sustainable production and consumption
To protect and restore biodiversity and ecosystem services we must move away from a fixation on economic growth and towards sustainable production and consumption
educate children on our native flora and fauna using art

We should reduce the pressure on our biodiversity by following the advice of the World Economic Forum and other major institutions to invest in creating a circular economy that minimises waste and makes the most of resources
We need to move rapidly towards farming practices that promote sustainable food production e.g. the use of locally produced food, using techniques such as permaculture, biodynamics, urban agriculture
It is the capitalist system, with its drive for ever increasing profits and extraction of natural resources, that is the cause of our environmental crisis
Healthy functioning nature is a collective good and private landowners should be compensated if they are protecting or restoring biodiversity or ecosystem services
Non-indigenous species and habitats can provide benefits for indigenous species
There are large amounts of land are in public ownership in NZ that could be used to enhance biodiversity (e.g. roadside reserves, schools)
Allowing the private sector to compete in providing biodiversity services would make them more effective and efficient, and drive innovation
Monitoring and evaluation of biodiversity management is crucial to ensure activities are effective and efficient
Biodiversity is not just a rural issue, there are many biodiversity problems in towns and cities
NZ‚Äôs economic success relies on both non-indigeneous and indigeneous species
While indigenous biodiversity should be given priority in protected areas, the rights and incomes of property owners must not be compromised on private land
There must be a programme in place to help MƒÅori graduates move into roles at the Department of Conservation and other organisations
There is a need to consider and remove or alter any legislative blocks that prevent whƒÅnau or hap≈´ from exercising kaitiakitanga/stewardship
MƒÅori must hold key roles in biodiversity governance structures
A partnership between tangata whenua and the Crown should reflect aspirations for the co-management of nature
The Biodiversity Strategy should recognise the Treaty of Waitangi and the principles of partnership, protection and participation
Priority should be given to developing humane ways of eradicating pests such as possums and rats at scale
Biodiversity management should recognise the value of mƒÅtauranga MƒÅori and practical knowledge, right from planning through to monitoring success
We should prioritise research and development into alternatives to 1080 poison
Roles and responsibilities in the biodiversity system need to be better defined and communicated
Non-indigenous ecosystems and species can be valuable for biodiversity and ecosystem services
The biodiversity system needs more collaborative decision-making that involves all affected parties
We must invest in science and technology to achieve the vision and long-term outcomes of the  Biodiversity Strategy
Local, district and regional plans and/or strategies, as well as national tools (e.g. National Policy Statements and legislation) should guide action on the ground
More money and resources must be spent to protect and restore biodiversity and ecosystem services
Nature has the right to exist for its own sake, regardless of any benefits we may get from it
Biodiversity management decisions need to be informed by the best available information
Our physical and mental health and prosperity depends on our natural environment
The Biodiversity Strategy needs to prioritise conserving our indigenous species

The Biodiversity Strategy should take an intergenerational view
